string.text: Surge Protector

A small albeit advanced device consisting of a ton of resistors and replaceable fuses. It protects the user by limiting the effective amount of electricity that comes into direct contact with the body through diverting it to the fuses, and subsequently blowing them. This makes it almost foolproof against Electro Anomalies, but it can only endure so many strong electric shocks before all the fuses are blown out. Most stalkers construct these devices with spare electronic trash, which is in no shortage in the Zone. Even though the device is heavy and disposable, it is extremely useful for navigating electrical anomaly fields. As with all metal objects, it can be used as a source of repair material as long as one has appropriate tools and enough skill.

Improved Surge Protector

An upgraded Surge Protector making use of an artifact to better disperse electrical shock. Errant surges electricity are routed through the same path, but due to the presence of the artifact, some shock is partially absorbed and the overall damage to the components is reduced. In addition, the artifact constantly emits a mild muscle relaxing current, which helps with soreness and fatigue.

Anomaly Suppression System

Advanced device with several scanners, transmitters, and emitters for radiowaves, electromagnetic waves, and high-pitch sonar waves. One of the first devices designed by the Ministry of Science to protect their field agents, this sophisticated machine embodies Suslov's 'tapping the fish tank' theory, where certain anomalies can be temporarily disrupted if enough environmental disturbance is introduced. The device automatically scans local anomalies and emits a combined neutralizing pulse in response to anomaly activation, effectively shutting it down temporarily and negating all hazard. Devices such as these form the bulk of active anomalous defense systems in the SSP and SEVA suits, which both feature integrated versions of this device. The device comes with a self-recharging battery for the suppression pulse, however, the onboard computer needs time to recalibrate and recalculate field changes that occur after each pulse. The device can be combined with the onboard support systems of the SSP and SEVA suits to enhance its effectiveness and recharge time.

Advanced Anomaly Suppression System

Next-generation anomaly suppression device incorporating telemetry data from rare artifact samples to compute suppression solutions more quickly. This device is the pinnacle of anomaly protection systems and is in extremely high demand with all science personnel, not to mention stalkers themselves. Additional data from the incorporated artifact sample allows pulses to be transmitted with less disturbance to the environment, allowing for recalibration cycles to occur more frequently. In addition, the device emits a constant field that passively reduces the strength of nearby anomaly fields. The device can be combined with the onboard support systems of the SSP and SEVA suits to enhance its effectiveness and recharge time.

SLSA 0.06.8 EM Autodoc Module

An outdated military-issue SLSA (System of Life Support, Automatic) Autodoc Module. For a short period of time following the Second Chernobyl Incident, the Ukrainian SSU invested in the development of a field-portable automatic doctor system to improve the effectiveness of their field personnel. These field doctor units were issued to several combat and exploration battalions, and while effective, they are quite unpopular amongst the standing armed forces. 
 The SLSA has three tanks, one for stabilizer, painkillers and antirads, The Autodoc is programmed to space out doses by at least 15 seconds to not overdose and kill the user.

SLSA 0.06.9 EM Improved Autodoc Module

An enhanced Autodoc Module improved with Zone technology. Based on the original Autodoc design, these advanced modules were designed using research and specimens gathered in the Zone. Application of carefully contained healing artifacts has both boosted the effectiveness of the administered medicine as well as passively encouraging cell growth. Small numbers of these Autodoc Modules have been produced owing in part to the difficulty in sourcing the right manufacturing materials. Despite that, they are highly popular and sought after amongst Spetsnaz units and Ecologists, even though the pain of the forearm injector is arguably worse than before.
 The SLSA has three tanks, one for stabilizer, painkillers and antirads, The Autodoc is programmed to space out doses by at least 15 seconds to not overdose and kill the user.

Aluminium frames

A decent-quality aluminum frame used to more efficiently distribute the weight of your pack. Aluminum is a relatively light and strong metal, and serves well as a means to distribute weight at the cost of making the user more conductive to electricity. Adjustable straps and harnesses allow the frame to be adjusted to any torso size, and flexible plastic elements used in key parts of the construction allow for a surprising amount of flexibility when sprinting. The grid replaces the main framework of your backpack, and as such must be mounted into a backpack. Although the system is built of light aluminium, some parts can still prove useful for minor outfit repairs.

Titanium grid

A high-quality titanium grid used to more efficiently distribute the weight of your pack. Titanium's light weight and high strength makes it a superior alternative to back frames constructed of aluminum, although it shares the same conductive properties as other metal frames. Adjustable straps and harnesses allow the grid to be adjusted to any torso size, and flexible plastic elements used in key parts of the construction allow for a surprising amount of flexibility when sprinting. The grid replaces the main framework of your backpack, and as such must be mounted into a backpack. Grids are created from very high quality titanium, thus disassembled grid can be used as an effective combat outfit or helmet repair supplement.

Camelbak

Borrowing its name from the myth that camels store water in their humps, the Camelbak is a pack worn on the back or around the waist of the user, containing a bladder that is filled with water to keep one hydrated. Flexible tube with a mouthpiece facilitates use even in most pressing situations. This model is camouflaged and integrated in the suit to protect the system from damage from any source, be it combat or anomaly. Because the container is made of a high-quality textile, experienced stalkers sometimes re-use scrapped camelbaks for quality materials to patch their field outfits.
